<h4 style="color:#495057; font-weight: bold;  text-align: left">Description</h4>

This function splits .csv raw data files into two separate files, adjusting the relative start time to “0” for each file.

<h4><a style="color:#495057; font-weight: bold;  text-align: left" name="Arguments">Arguments</a></h4>


  Argument       | Description | Default
---: | :------------- | :---
**data**            | The name of the “.csv” data file must be split. A character string. | --
**split_data_name** | The name that is used for split output files. A character string.| --
**cycle_full_min**  | The duration of a full cycle (flush + measure; minutes) for the second part, presumably the SMR/RMR section. This is only used for visual assessment purposes. | --
**time split**       | The relative time that defines the split (in minutes). | --
**date_format**     | The format of the date. Must be either: `"m/d/y"`, `"d/m/y"`, `"y-m-d"`. | `NULL`
**split**           | Logical argument. When `TRUE`, the original file is cut, and 2 files are exported or saved in the local directory. | `FALSE`
**N_Ch**            | The number of FireSting channels. Use 4 or 8. If a 2-Channel FireSting was used, this argument could be ignored |4   

<br><h4><a name="Value" style="color:#495057; font-weight: bold;  text-align: left">Value</a></h4>

The function may be useful when one data file contains both i) the manually timed MMR measurements and ii) automatically timed repeat measurement cycles to estimate SMR/RMR. These two parts are analyzed here using different functions, `MMR` and `SMR`, each requiring its own ‘.csv’ datafiles. 

Alternatively, this function can be valuable if one continuous SMR/RMR file contains data collected on two differently timed repeat measurement cycles (e.g., 7:8 minute flush: measure, transitioned into 9:6 minute flush: measure). 



<h5 style="color:#495057; font-weight: bold;  text-align: left; text-indent:+10px;"><i class="fas fa-ellipsis-h"></i>&nbsp; Data outputs</h5>

**“.csv” files**

- Saved in the current local working directory; only if `split = TRUE`
- Export data file, the first part (MMR part):
  * has name extension “mmr_split.csv”
  * ready as an input file for `MMR` function
- Export data file, the second part (RMR part):
  * has name extension “smr_split.csv”
  * ready as an input file for `SMR` function

**“.png” files**

- "split_data_(…)_respo_cycles.png”
  * all data displayed with vertical lines indicating the: i) split time and ii) the cycle durations for the second part that is assumed to be on auto-cycles. 
- "split_data_(…)_respo_confirm.png”
  * a zoomed-in version (2 min) of the O~2~ versus time data, specifically at the section of the split time. The lines indicate where the 'split' occurs when `split = TRUE`. 
  

<br><h4><a name="Details" style="color:#495057; font-weight: bold;  text-align: left">Details</a></h4> <br>

<br><h4><a name="Example" style="color:#495057; font-weight: bold;  text-align: left">Example</a></h4> <br>

<pre class = "sourceCode yaml"> 

csv_file_split(data="Sep24_2019_box0_fullfile.csv",
               split_data_name="Sep24_2019_box0_TEST-8ch", # note to use the naming system for easy downstream work
               cycle_full_min=10,
               timeSplit=42,
               split=FALSE,
               N_Ch=8,
               date_format="d/m/y")

</pre>
